awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Autonomous Hierarchical Adaptive Dynamic Programming for Decision Making in Complex Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent big wave of artificial intelligence (AI) not only provided tremendous advancements ranging from fundamental research to a wide range of exciting applications, but also presents enormous amounts of opportunities as well as challenges to the community. Among many of the AI techniques, adaptive dynamic programming and reinforcement learning (ADP/RL) is widely considered as one of the key methodologies for learning-based intelligent decision-making process.

The objective of this project is to develop an innovative autonomous hierarchical ADP/RL approach for decision making in complex environments. By autonomously providing a hierarchical representation of sub-goals for improved learning and exploration capability, the proposed research provides a new approach to systematically and adaptively develop an optimal multi-step hierarchical temporal abstraction sequence, rather than the one-step primitive action in traditional methods. The research method advances the foundations, principles, architectures, and algorithms for autonomous learning and hierarchical control, which will facilitate the capability of learning and generalization for decision-making. This project provides unique opportunities to attract and educate future professionals by bridging the connections of ADP/RL and energy systems, and for students to work on cutting-edge problems. The team consists of two PIs with strong collaborations and complementary expertise in computational intelligence, machine learning, autonomous control, and the smart grid.

This research advances the scientific foundations and methodologies of intelligent decision making in complex environments with high-dimensionality, big data, and uncertainty.  The collaborations with industry integrates fundamental research into a microgrid application providing critical technical innovations to the energy sector. In addition, the developed ADP/RL based intelligent decision making method can benefit other types of complex engineering systems. Furthermore, the research results of this project are also expected to fulfill a critical need in the community by training and preparing future workforce in the cross-disciplinary areas of machine learning and energy systems. The integrative outreach and education activities will provide unique opportunities to attract women and minorities into the intelligent system and smart grid field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Over the past decade, computational intelligence and machine learning have demonstrated tremendous success and excitement across a wide range of domains. However, decision making in complex environment still presents enormous amounts of opportunities as well as challenges to the community. Among many of the computational intelligence methods, reinforcement learning and adaptive dynamic programming is considered as one of the important methodologies for scaling learning-based intelligent decision-making process. To this end, this project advances the learning strategies based on reinforcement learning and adaptive dynamic programming, and study their applications to power and energy systems. 

Specifically, the team has developed numerous computational intelligence and machine learning methods with a focus on reinforcement learning and adaptive dynamic programming. This includes deep reinforcement learning algorithms, neural network based learning and control, multi-view data clustering, multi-agent based learning and cooperation, domain adaptation learning, reinforcement learning policy iteration, trust region policy optimization, among others. The application of these methods in power and energy systems have also been studied during this project period. Comprehensive modeling and simulations have been carried out to verify the effectiveness of the developed methods. The outcomes of this project are significant, ranging from new knowledge and methods on machine learning and computational intelligence, to education and outreach activities. Over the project period, the team published numerous peer-reviewed articles in the major journals in the field, such as IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, IEEE transactions on cybernetics, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control,  and IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid. The research results have also been presented at major international conferences such as International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), International Joint Conference on Neural Networks (IJCNN), IEEE Symposium Series on Computational Intelligence (SSCI), among others. This project also provided many opportunities for students training and mentoring, with the involvement of graduate students and undergraduate students into research. For example, multiple graduate students graduated during the project period, and one of them has joined academia as a tenure-track assistant professor.

The results generated in this project bridge different disciplines in machine learning, computational intelligence, adaptive control, and power and energy systems. This project also provided important opportunities for educational and outreach activities, including the engagement and collaborations with the Energy Fellows Program and International Engineering Program (IEP) at the University of Rhode Island (URI), and mentoring of summer internship undergraduate students. 

 


Last Modified: 08/23/2023
Modified by: Haibo He
